body:
this looks reasonable to me, except ...
1. I recall there are issues with underscores in the filename, as well, which is why I always use hyphens (`-`) in filenames instead of spaces. 
2. I think we don't need another copy of a notebook just for this test, and instead, just rename one of the notebooks we have to include spaces in the name. The reason is that when we update the test notebooks, we don't want to have to remember to updated it in two places. You can do that using something like

``` python
with self.create_temp_cwd(['notebook1.ipynb']):
    os.rename('notebook1.ipynb', 'notebook with spaces.ipynb')
```

can you make those changes and `git commit --amend` followed by a `git push --force` to update this PR?

pinging @jdfreder and @Carreau for further review, since they've been doing a bunch of nbconvert work.

Hello,

On 4 Aug 2013, at 21:40, Paul Ivanov notifications@github.com wrote:

> this looks reasonable to me, except ...
> 
>   • I recall there are issues with underscores in the filename, as well, which is why I always use hyphens (-) in filenames instead of spaces.

I haven't done this because the directory with the generated files is already called <notebook name>_files.  I agree that hyphens are better, but a mixture is probably not helpful and I didn't want to alter other's design decisions.

>   • I think we don't need another copy of a notebook just for this test, and instead, just rename one of the notebooks we have to include spaces in the name. The reason is that when we update the test notebooks, we don't want to have to remember to updated it in two places. You can do that using something like
> 
> with self.create_temp_cwd(['notebook1.ipynb']):
> 
> os.rename('notebook1.ipynb', 'notebook with spaces.ipynb')

Done.

I wouldn't object to switching to hyphens, nor would I object to using grffile. If it were me, I would just use grffile, since I think the inability to handle spaces in paths is a fundamentally unacceptable limitation of software that interacts with the filesystem.
